authors.name: The Abercrombie Method
authors.description: Universal Storytelling Rules: These rules guide all narrative creation to ensure character-centric, gritty, and nuanced storytelling regardless of genre. POINT OF VIEW & INTIMATE CHARACTER VOICE: Use tight third-person limited POV where every detail is filtered through a single character's consciousness. All descriptions must be rooted in the viewpoint character's immediate experience and perception, focusing on emotionally relevant details. Maintain flexibility to shift between multiple limited perspectives to highlight subjective truth. Every viewpoint character must possess a unique, recognizable voice with distinct vocabulary, rhythm, and prose style. GRITTY REALISM & MORAL AMBIGUITY: Portray realities unflinchingly, stripping away romanticism. Violence should be painful, dirty, and unpleasant with lasting damage. Include mundane yet impactful details of human existence to ground the extraordinary in uncomfortable reality. Characters and situations must exist in shades of grey - avoid purely good or evil archetypes. Explore that 'everyone thinks they're good, and good people in bad corners might have to do bad things.' Ensure even 'bad' characters have believable, relatable motivations. DIALOGUE & ECONOMICAL DESCRIPTION: Craft dialogue that is snappy, distinctive, and serves multiple purposes - revealing character, advancing plot, and injecting dark humor. Use evocative yet economical description focusing on telling details rather than verbose passages. Descriptions should reflect the viewpoint character's emotional reaction, making description itself a form of characterization. SUBVERSION OF TROPES & CHARACTER ARCS: Challenge traditional heroic archetypes with deeply flawed, morally compromised protagonists. Their arcs should be complex, often leading to disillusionment or cyclical struggles rather than clear redemption. Defy conventional plot structures by setting up expectations only to subvert them with surprising yet earned outcomes. Conclusions should feel earned and reflect grim reality rather than idealized endings. NARRATIVE PROGRESSION: Story progression must be character-centric, with information revealed in 'slow drips' as relevant to the viewpoint character's journey. Environmental details should be seamlessly integrated through the character's experience, contributing to gritty realism and influencing their actions and emotional state.

authors.name: Frank McCourt
authors.description: Craft memoir with humor and pathos, finding light in dark circumstances. Use distinctive voice and vivid detail to bring personal history to life.

authors.name: Tara Westover
authors.description: Create compelling narratives about education, family, and self-discovery. Focus on the tension between loyalty to family and personal growth.

authors.name: Ursula K. Le Guin
authors.description: Craft thoughtful science fiction that explores social and political themes through alien societies. Focus on anthropological speculation, gender dynamics, and philosophical questions about human nature.

authors.name: Philip K. Dick
authors.description: Create paranoid, reality-bending narratives that question the nature of consciousness and reality. Explore themes of identity, memory, and the impact of technology on human experience.

authors.name: J.G. Ballard
authors.description: Develop experimental science fiction that examines the psychological effects of technology and modern life. Focus on inner space rather than outer space, exploring human obsessions and desires.

authors.name: Kurt Vonnegut
authors.description: Blend science fiction with dark humor and anti-war themes. Use unconventional narrative structures and satirical elements to comment on human nature and society.

authors.name: Stanisław Lem
authors.description: Create philosophical science fiction that explores the limits of human understanding. Focus on first contact scenarios and the impossibility of truly comprehending alien intelligence.

authors.name: Raymond Chandler
authors.description: Craft hard-boiled detective fiction with atmospheric urban settings and morally ambiguous characters. Use first-person narration and poetic language to explore corruption and cynicism.

authors.name: Dashiell Hammett
authors.description: Create lean, tough crime stories with realistic dialogue and complex plots. Focus on professional criminals and detectives operating in morally gray worlds.

authors.name: James Ellroy
authors.description: Develop dark, complex crime narratives set in corrupt urban environments. Use staccato prose and multiple perspectives to explore police corruption and political conspiracy.

authors.name: Jim Thompson
authors.description: Craft psychological crime fiction that explores the dark side of American life. Focus on unreliable narrators and the thin line between sanity and madness.

authors.name: Chester Himes
authors.description: Create gritty urban crime stories that address racial tensions and social inequality. Blend hard-boiled detective fiction with social commentary.

style: Stand Up Comedy (in first person pov and style of Nate Bargatze)

authors.name: Nate Bargatze
authors.description: Craft observational comedy in a conversational, self-deprecating style. Focus on everyday situations, family life, and personal mishaps told with deadpan delivery and Midwestern sensibility. Use simple, relatable humor that finds the absurd in ordinary experiences.

authors.name: Jerry Seinfeld
authors.description: Create comedy that finds humor in the minutiae of daily life. Focus on observational humor about social conventions, relationships, and the absurdities of modern living.

authors.name: Brian Regan
authors.description: Develop clean, physical comedy that relies on storytelling and animated delivery. Focus on childhood memories, family dynamics, and universal experiences.

authors.name: Jim Gaffigan
authors.description: Craft self-deprecating humor about food, family, and laziness. Use internal monologue and audience perspective to create layered comedy.

authors.name: Mike Birbiglia
authors.description: Create narrative-driven comedy that blends personal stories with broader observations. Focus on vulnerability, awkward situations, and finding humor in life's challenges.
